channel.title: Java use 140k memory?
channel.description:
Pi 317
Da f.. 140k-170k memory java running my client.. Memory leak?? How can i find it.

item.title: Java use 140k memory?
item.dc:creator: @Illadelph Illadelph
item.description:
@Illadelph wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:16, topic:473921”][quote author=Illadelph link=topic=591853.msg4183238#msg4183238 date=1355788078]
a lot of the leaks r with … catch(Exception _ex) { }
[/quote]
what the actual love are you talking about LOL, that’s exception handling, you would have to be a complete idiot to remove all the exception handling…[/quote]

No… these current ones… i have a program to tell me any wrong codes that have been put on my client/server. And these are performance issues. instead of making the methods… but idk lol. Just been using the program for 2-4 hours. trying to figure it out better

Read full topic

item.title: Java use 140k memory?
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“Clawz fury, post:16, topic:473921”][quote author=Illadelph link=topic=591853.msg4183238#msg4183238 date=1355788078]
a lot of the leaks r with … catch(Exception _ex) { }
[/quote]
what the actual love are you talking about LOL, that’s exception handling, you would have to be a complete idiot to remove all the exception handling…[/quote]It’s not a leak; it’s more of a performance issue. You could remove most of them and have either the method throw the exception, or one exception encapsulating the others.

item.title: Java use 140k memory?
item.dc:creator: @Illadelph Illadelph
item.description:
@Illadelph wrote:

not all pi’s are bad. Iv seen some good ones with some nice memory use… I guess me + visualvm have some time to do. ughhgh. Still looking for updates in post aswell if you have any fixes for memory leaks with this client thanks.

Just found this code

l += j1 - equipment[5] << 40;     <-- its shifting by 40.. what should it be shifting by  32?

int i9 = i3;
int l9 = l2;
if(l2 < i9)
i9 = l2;
if(l2 > l9)
l9 = l2;
if(l < i9)
i9 = l;
if(l > l9)
l9 = l;
if(k2 < i9)
i9 = k2;
if(k2 > l9)
l9 = k2;
i9 /= 14;
l9 /= 14;
}

also whats wrong with this??
System.arraycopy(buffer, i, abyte0, i - i, currentOffset - 1 - i);
return abyte0;

aMRUNodes_238 = null;

Here are all the leaks iv found so far. to all the people who using same client as me

a lot of the leaks r with … catch(Exception _ex) { }

item.title: Java use 140k memory?
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

zyle1992:

I wish my server only used 14KB of RAM. That would be lovely.

140k = 70MB (Windows is loveing retarded). It says I have ‘2M’ of available memory, however it’s actually 1GB… Increase the unit, divide by two to get the real value. >.>

Read full topic

item.title: Java use 140k memory?
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

Illadelph:

This forum has really gone 2 shit.

What the fuck are you talking about? You haven’t even been here long enough to see if the forums has gone to shit. I’ve been here almost 3 years and I still get asked by some people who have been here longer if I’m ‘new’.

Plus you use PI so you really shouldn’t be talking about what’s shit.

On topic: Stupidity can cause memory leaks too, for example, say you have something like this:

[code=java]package server;

// this class represents a global item
public class GlobalItem {

// an integer uses 4 bytes
// so 4*4 = 16 bytes here
private int i;
private int j;
private int k;;
private int z;

// 8 bytes in a long
private long o;

// constructor
GlobalItem(int i, int j, int k, long o) {
	setI(i);
	setJ(j);
	setK(k);
	setO(o);
}

/**
 * @return the o
 */
public long getO() {
	return o;
}

/**
 * @param o
 *            the o to set
 */
public void setO(long o) {
	this.o = o;
}

/**
 * @return the z
 */
public int getZ() {
	return z;
}

/**
 * @param z
 *            the z to set
 */
public void setZ(int z) {
	this.z = z;
}

/**
 * @return the k
 */
public int getK() {
	return k;
}

/**
 * @param k
 *            the k to set
 */
public void setK(int k) {
	this.k = k;
}

/**
 * @return the j
 */
public int getJ() {
	return j;
}

/**
 * @param j
 *            the j to set
 */
public void setJ(int j) {
	this.j = j;
}

/**
 * @return the i
 */
public int getI() {
	return i;
}

/**
 * @param i
 *            the i to set
 */
public void setI(int i) {
	this.i = i;
}

}
[/code]

in total class has 24 bytes, doesn’t seem like much right? Lets say some idiot wants a max amount of global items, so he does this

would cause 2147000000 new global item objects to be created, and how much bytes are in each object? 24.

So how much memory is being used? 24*2147000000 = 51528000000 bytes of memory, or 47.989189624785155GB of memory!! 48GB!

Now you see how stupid simple things can tear apart your memory usage.

Hope I helped a bit.

Read full topic

item.title: Java use 140k memory?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Illadelph, post:5, topic:473921”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=591853.msg4182704#msg4182704 date=1355722619]
Memory leaks can be caused by unused process in the client that are being called for no apparent reason. Try removing content that is there, that has no use.
[/quote]

ooo thanks. dropped it down by 10k already. Any good spots to look specifically for unused processes?

do all those // methods use up memory?[/quote]
// “Methods” are comments… They are ignored by the compiler.
Same with these:
/**
*
*
*/

Read full topic
